text: Then shall I not be ashamed, when I have respect unto all thy commandments.
text_kjv: Then shall I not be ashamed, when I have respect unto all thy commandments.
text_niv: Then I would not be put to shamewhen I consider all your commands.
text_esv: Then I shall not be put to shame, having my eyes fixed on all your commandments.
text_nlt: Then I will not be ashamedwhen I compare my life with your commands.
text_msg: Then I'd never have any regretsin comparing my life with your counsel.
text_nasb: Then I shall not be ashamed When I look upon all Your commandments.
context: Psalm 119 is an acrostic poem, with each of its 176 verses dedicated to the praise and exposition of God's law. It's divided into 22 stanzas, one for each letter of the Hebrew alphabet. This verse, Psalm 119:6, falls within the stanza designated by the letter 'Dalet.' Understanding the historical and cultural milieu of the Psalm provides crucial insight. The Psalmist likely lived in a society where adherence to the Mosaic Law was paramount, serving as both a religious and societal framework. Disobedience could result in public shame and ostracization. During periods of Israel's history, like the exile, maintaining faithfulness to the Law became a symbol of national identity and resistance against assimilation into foreign cultures. The concept of 'shame' was deeply intertwined with honor in ancient Near Eastern societies. Public humiliation and social disgrace were significant deterrents. The law wasn't just a set of rules, but a pathway to a blessed and flourishing life, both individually and as a nation. Thus, Psalm 119's author expresses a profound desire for complete and unwavering adherence to God's precepts, seeking to avoid the shame associated with disobedience and instead, embracing the honor that comes from aligning one's life with divine will. The very act of writing, preserving, and reciting such a Psalm highlights the commitment to passing down the importance of the Law to future generations.
meaning: Psalm 119:6 expresses the direct correlation between obedience to God's commandments and the avoidance of shame. The verse isn't suggesting a mere performance of outward acts of righteousness, but a deep 'respect unto all thy commandments.' This 'respect' (Hebrew: שָׁעָה, sha'ah) implies a thoughtful consideration, a careful regard, and a devoted attention to the entirety of God's law. It speaks to an internal disposition of reverence and awe, rather than just external compliance. The 'shame' (Hebrew: בּוֹשׁ, bosh) is not merely social disgrace but a deeper sense of disappointment and regret before God. It signifies a falling short of God's standard and a violation of His holy character. The Psalmist's confidence stems from the belief that sincere obedience, born out of genuine respect, leads to integrity and inner peace. This is not a claim of sinless perfection, but rather an aspiration towards wholehearted devotion. The verse highlights the comprehensive nature of obedience. It emphasizes 'all' God's commandments, suggesting that selective obedience is insufficient. True righteousness is demonstrated through consistent and comprehensive adherence to God's revealed will. This verse reflects the Old Testament understanding of the covenant relationship between God and His people. Obedience is not a means of earning salvation, but rather a response to God's grace and a demonstration of love and loyalty.
application: Psalm 119:6 offers profound implications for contemporary Christian living. In a world increasingly relativistic and morally ambiguous, the verse underscores the importance of grounding our lives in God's unchanging truth. The concept of 'shame' can be a powerful motivator for righteousness. However, we must distinguish between godly sorrow, which leads to repentance, and worldly shame, which can be crippling and unproductive. Our primary motivation for obedience should not be the avoidance of shame or societal disapproval, but a deep love for God and a desire to honor Him. The phrase 'respect unto all thy commandments' calls us to examine our own lives and identify areas where we may be selectively obedient. Are there certain commandments we tend to ignore or rationalize away? Comprehensive obedience requires a continuous process of self-examination, repentance, and reliance on the Holy Spirit's guidance. In practice, this means studying God's Word diligently, applying its principles to all areas of our lives, and seeking accountability with fellow believers. We are called to resist the temptation to compromise our values in the face of cultural pressure or personal convenience. Living a life of integrity and unwavering commitment to God's Word will ultimately result in a sense of inner peace and confidence. Embracing biblical principles in areas like finances, relationships, and social interactions can bring us closer to God, help us avoid many pitfalls, and ultimately lead to a life of purpose, joy, and fulfillment. It's a daily commitment to aligning our thoughts, words, and actions with God's will.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you acknowledging my imperfections and shortcomings. I confess that I have often fallen short of your perfect standard. I ask for your forgiveness and cleansing. Grant me a heart that truly respects all your commandments, not just those that are convenient or easy to follow. Fill me with your Holy Spirit, empowering me to live a life of integrity and obedience. Help me to discern your will in all areas of my life and to resist the temptations that lead to shame and regret. May my life be a reflection of your love and grace, bringing honor to your name. Help me to have godly sorrow when I stumble, and to quickly repent and seek your grace. Thank you for your unwavering love and mercy. In Jesus' name, Amen.
